elements.content: Studies of the anion effects on the molecular construction of a series of AgX complexes with bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) have been carried out. Formation of the skeletal bonds appears to be primarily associated with a suitable combination of bidentate N-donors of L and a variety of coordination geometries of Ag(I) ions. The L:Ag(I) ratios of the products are dependent on the nature of the polyatomic anions. The 1:1 adduct Ag(I)−L for NO2 -, 3:4 adduct for NO3 -, 2:3 adduct for CF3SO3 -, and 1:2 adduct for PF6 - have been obtained. A linear relationship between the ratio of ligand to metal and the coordinating ability of anions was observed. [Ag(NO2)(L)] has a unique sheet structure consisting of double helices, and [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 is a 2 nm thick interwoven sheet structure consisting of nanotubes. The compound [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2 affords a characteristic ladder-type channel structure, and [Ag(L)2](PF6) is a simple 2D grid structure.
elements.clean_text: Studies of the anion effects on the molecular construction of a series of AgX complexes with bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) have been carried out. Formation of the skeletal bonds appears to be primarily associated with a suitable combination of bidentate N-donors of L and a variety of coordination geometries of Ag(I) ions. The L:Ag(I) ratios of the products are dependent on the nature of the polyatomic anions. The 1:1 adduct Ag(I)-L for NO2 -, 3:4 adduct for NO3 -, 2:3 adduct for CF3SO3 -, and 1:2 adduct for PF6 - have been obtained. A linear relationship between the ratio of ligand to metal and the coordinating ability of anions was observed. [Ag(NO2)(L)] has a unique sheet structure consisting of double helices, and [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 is a 2 nm thick interwoven sheet structure consisting of nanotubes. The compound [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2 affords a characteristic ladder-type channel structure, and [Ag(L)2](PF6) is a simple 2D grid structure.

elements.content: For the self-assembly of a series of AgX with bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -), the mole ratio of L to Ag(I) depends on the coordinating ability of the anions:  Ag(I)−L adducts of 1:1 (for NO2 -), 3:4 (for NO3 -), 2:3 (for CF3SO3 -), and 1:2 (for PF6 -) ratio.
elements.clean_text: For the self-assembly of a series of AgX with bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -), the mole ratio of L to Ag(I) depends on the coordinating ability of the anions: Ag(I)-L adducts of 1:1 (for NO2 -), 3:4 (for NO3 -), 2:3 (for CF3SO3 -), and 1:2 (for PF6 -) ratio.

elements.content: The rational design and construction of functional coordination materials with specific motifs is a fruitful field since the materials have various potential applications such as molecular separation, toxic materials adsorption, molecular containers, ion exchangers, molecular recognition, and luminescent sensors. Thus, various kinds of framework materials have been constructed by the coordinations of metal ions with spacer ligands. The molecular geometry and flexibility of multidentate N-donor spacer ligands play key roles in the development of the tailor-made molecular materials. Recently, we have demonstrated that various silicon-containing pyridyl spacer ligands are useful for the synthesis of desirable skeletal structures. Exploitation of the silicon-containing pyridine-based ligands has produced a variety of coordination modes since the ligands are adjustable in their potential bridging ability, possess flexible interligand angles at silicon, and are conformationally nonrigid. Furthermore, the counteranions can play crucial roles in the molecular construction since the anions have many features such as negative charge, size, and geometry, and display variable differences, significant solvent effects, and pH dependence. Recent developments in anion chemistry include exciting advances in anion template assembly, ion-pair recognition, and the function of supramolecular materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and construction of functional coordination materials with specific motifs is a fruitful field since the materials have various potential applications such as molecular separation, toxic materials adsorption, molecular containers, ion exchangers, molecular recognition, and luminescent sensors. Thus, various kinds of framework materials have been constructed by the coordinations of metal ions with spacer ligands. The molecular geometry and flexibility of multidentate N-donor spacer ligands play key roles in the development of the tailor-made molecular materials. Recently, we have demonstrated that various silicon-containing pyridyl spacer ligands are useful for the synthesis of desirable skeletal structures. Exploitation of the silicon-containing pyridine-based ligands has produced a variety of coordination modes since the ligands are adjustable in their potential bridging ability, possess flexible interligand angles at silicon, and are conformationally nonrigid. Furthermore, the counteranions can play crucial roles in the molecular construction since the anions have many features such as negative charge, size, and geometry, and display variable differences, significant solvent effects,  and pH dependence. Recent developments in anion chemistry include exciting advances in anion template assembly, ion-pair recognition, and the function of supramolecular materials.

elements.content: In an effort to expand the roles of anions in the molecular construction, the slow diffusion reactions of AgX (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) with bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) were carried out and scrutinized. The Ag(I) ion has been employed as various directional units such as linear, T-shaped, and tetrahedral geometry.
elements.clean_text: In an effort to expand the roles of anions in the molecular construction, the slow diffusion reactions of AgX (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) with bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) were carried out and scrutinized. The Ag(I) ion has been employed as various directional units such as linear, T-shaped, and tetrahedral geometry.

elements.content:
<fig id="ic048537rf1" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic xlink:href="ic-2004-08537r_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Materials and Measurements. AgX (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) were purchased from Strem, and were used without further purification. Bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) was prepared according to the literature procedure. [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 was recently published as a Communication. Elemental microanalyses (C, H, N) were performed on crystalline samples by the Advanced Analysis Center at KIST using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction data were recorded on a Rigaku RINT/DMAX-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV and 126 mA for Cu Kα. Thermal analyses were carried out under a dinitrogen atmosphere at a scan rate of 10 °C/min using a Stanton Red Croft TG 100. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 16F PC FTIR spectrophotometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Measurements. AgX (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) were purchased from Strem, and were used without further purification. Bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) was prepared according to the literature procedure. [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 was recently published as a Communication. Elemental microanalyses (C, H, N) were performed on crystalline samples by the Advanced Analysis Center at KIST using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction data were recorded on a Rigaku RINT/DMAX-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV and 126 mA for Cu Kα. Thermal analyses were carried out under a dinitrogen atmosphere at a scan rate of 10 °C/min using a Stanton Red Croft TG 100. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 16F PC FTIR spectrophotometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets.

elements.content: [Ag(NO 2 )(L)]. A methanol solution (6 mL) of L (43 mg, 0.20 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (6 mL) of AgNO2 (30 mg, 0.20 mmol). Colorless crystals of [Ag(NO2)(L)] formed at the interface, and were obtained in 6 days in 70% yield. Mp:  164 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C12H14N3O2SiAg:  C, 39.14; H, 3.83; N, 11.41. Found:  C, 40.04; H, 3,77; N, 11.14. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν(NO2), 1254 (s).

Colorless crystals of [Ag(NO2)(L)] formed at the interface, and were obtained in 6 days in 70% yield. Mp: 164 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C12H14N3O2SiAg: C, 39.14; H, 3.83; N, 11.41. Found: C, 40.04; H, 3,77; N, 11.14. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν(NO2), 1254 (s).

elements.content: [Ag 2 (L) 3 ](CF 3 SO 3 ) 2 . A methanol solution of L was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution of AgCF3SO3 in a mole ratio of 1:1. Yield: 70% based on Ag(I) salt. Mp:  252 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C38H42N6O6F6S2Si3Ag2:  C, 39.45; H, 3.66; N, 7.26. Found:  C, 40.01; H, 3,76; N, 7.24. The crystals were obtained as a methanol solvate, but the elemental analysis was accomplished after desolvation under vacuum. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν(CF3SO3), 814 (s).

Mp: 252 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C38H42N6O6F6S2Si3Ag2: C, 39.45; H, 3.66; N, 7.26. Found: C, 40.01; H, 3,76; N, 7.24. The crystals were obtained as a methanol solvate, but the elemental analysis was accomplished after desolvation under vacuum. IR (KBr, cm-1): ν(CF3SO3), 814 (s).

elements.content: [Ag(L) 2 ](PF 6 ). This reaction was carried out by a similar method using acetone instead of methanol as a solvent. Yield:  70%. Mp:  210 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C24H28N4PF6Si2Ag:  C, 42.40; H, 4.14; N, 8.22. Found:  C, 42.30; H, 4.18; N, 8.48. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν(PF6), 838 (s). The crystals were obtained as an acetone solvate, but the elemental analysis was accomplished after desolvation under vacuum.

The crystals were obtained as an acetone solvate, but the elemental analysis was accomplished after desolvation under vacuum.

elements.content: Crystallographic Structure Determinations. X-ray data were collected on a Bruker SMART automatic diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a CCD detector at ambient temperature. The 45 frames of two-dimensional diffraction images were collected and processed to obtain the cell parameters and orientation matrix. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption effects were corrected by the empirical ψ-scan method. The structures were solved by the direct method (SHELXS 97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXL 97). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined only for the isotropic thermal factors. Crystal parameters and procedural information corresponding to data collection and structure refinement are given in Table .
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic Structure Determinations. X-ray data were collected on a Bruker SMART automatic diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and a CCD detector at ambient temperature. The 45 frames of two-dimensional diffraction images were collected and processed to obtain the cell parameters and orientation matrix. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption effects were corrected by the empirical ψ-scan method. The structures were solved by the direct method (SHELXS 97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXL 97). The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined only for the isotropic thermal factors. Crystal parameters and procedural information corresponding to data collection and structure refinement are given in Table .

a  R1 = ∑||F o| − |F c||/∑|F o|. b  wR2 = ∑w(F o 2 - F c 2)2/∑w F o 2)1/2.

Synthesis. The slow diffusion of an organic solution of bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) into an aqueous solution of AgX (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) afforded the 1:1 Ag(I)−L adduct for NO2 -, 3:4 adduct for NO3 -, 2:3 adduct for CF3SO3 -, and 1:2 adduct for PF6 -, presumably owing to the different coordinating natures of the anions (Scheme ). The ratios are exactly coincident with the order of coordinating ability of the anions as established in our previous results. The slow diffusion reactions were originally conducted at a 1:1 mole ratio of Ag(I) and L, but the products were not significantly affected by the mole ratio. Moreover, when acetone or ethanol was used as solvent instead of methanol, the same products were obtained. That is, the assembled structures were dependent only on the anions. The reaction of AgNO2 with L produces a unique sheet structure consisting of double helices, whereas the treatment of AgPF6 with L gives a simple network structure. [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 was a 2 nm thick interwoven sheet structure consisting of nanotubes. The reaction of AgCF3SO3 with L affords a unique 1D ladder channel structure. All the crystalline products are insoluble in water and common organic solvents, and are stable for several days even in aqueous suspensions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. The slow diffusion of an organic solution of bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (L) into an aqueous solution of AgX (X- = NO2 -, NO3 -, CF3SO3 -, and PF6 -) afforded the 1:1 Ag(I)-L adduct for NO2 -, 3:4 adduct for NO3 -, 2:3 adduct for CF3SO3 -, and 1:2 adduct for PF6 -, presumably owing to the different coordinating natures of the anions (Scheme ). The ratios are exactly coincident with the order of coordinating ability of the anions as established in our previous results. The slow diffusion reactions were originally conducted at a 1:1 mole ratio of Ag(I) and L, but the products were not significantly affected by the mole ratio. Moreover, when acetone or ethanol was used as solvent instead of methanol, the same products were obtained. That is, the assembled structures were dependent only on the anions. The reaction of AgNO2 with L produces a unique sheet structure consisting of double helices, whereas the treatment of AgPF6 with L gives a simple network structure. [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 was a 2 nm thick interwoven sheet structure consisting of nanotubes. The reaction of AgCF3SO3 with L affords a unique 1D ladder channel structure. All the crystalline products are insoluble in water and common organic solvents, and are stable for several days even in aqueous suspensions.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="ic048537rh00001" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic xlink:href="ic-2004-08537r_0003.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Structures. The crystal structure of [Ag(NO2)(L)] is shown in Figure , and relevant structural data are listed in Table . Each L connects two Ag(I) ions (Ag−N = 2.231(8) and 2.240(8) Å) to form a helix (helical pitch 19.298(2) Å). Each single helix twists the adjacent helix (phase difference 9.649(2) Å) to form an elegant double helix that is comparable to the structure of [Ag(bpp)](CF3SO3). The formation of helical molecules may be attributed to a favorable combination of the skewed conformer of L and the appropriate geometry around the N−Ag−N bonds. The nitrite anion is chelated to the Ag(I) ion (Ag−O(1) = 2.43(1) Å, Ag−O(2) = 2.51(1) Å). The angle N(1)−Ag−N(2) (126.9(3)°) indicates that the nitrite acts as a bidentate ligand rather than a simple counteranion. The double helices are connected to each other via the Ag···Ag interactions (3.002(2) Å) to form a unique sheet. The unique sheet is similar to that of [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](ClO4). The interaction distance is similar to the known closed-shell d10 Ag···Ag interactions. The argentophilic interaction is shorter than the van der Waals radii (3.44 Å), and is rather close to the Ag−Ag distance in silver metal (2.89 Å). That is, the Ag(I) ion may be best described as five-coordinate. Even though the nitrite acts as a bidentate, the central Ag(I) ion has a five-coordination number including an argentophilic Ag···Ag interaction, which will be explained in detail.
elements.clean_text: Structures. The crystal structure of [Ag(NO2)(L)] is shown in Figure , and relevant structural data are listed in Table . Each L connects two Ag(I) ions (Ag-N = 2.231(8) and 2.240(8) Å) to form a helix (helical pitch 19.298(2) Å). Each single helix twists the adjacent helix (phase difference 9.649(2) Å) to form an elegant double helix that is comparable to the structure of [Ag(bpp)](CF3SO3). The formation of helical molecules may be attributed to a favorable combination of the skewed conformer of L and the appropriate geometry around the N-Ag-N bonds. The nitrite anion is chelated to the Ag(I) ion (Ag-O(1) = 2.43(1) Å, Ag-O(2) = 2.51(1) Å). The angle N(1)-Ag-N(2) (126.9(3)°) indicates that the nitrite acts as a bidentate ligand rather than a simple counteranion. The double helices are connected to each other via the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions (3.002(2) Å) to form a unique sheet. The unique sheet is similar to that of [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](ClO4). The interaction distance is similar to the known closed-shell d10 Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions. The argentophilic interaction is shorter than the van der Waals radii (3.44 Å), and is rather close to the Ag-Ag distance in silver metal (2.89 Å). That is, the Ag(I) ion may be best described as five-coordinate. Even though the nitrite acts as a bidentate, the central Ag(I) ion has a five-coordination number including an argentophilic Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction, which will be explained in detail.

elements.content:
Selected Bond Parameters and Structural Features

[Ag(NO2)(L)] [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 a [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2· 2CH3OH [Ag(L)2](PF6)·1/2CH3C(O)CH3 Ag−N (Å) 2.231(8), 2.240(8) 2.14(1)−2.34(1) 2.244(7)−2.311(8) 2.266(5)−2.419(5) N−Ag−N (deg) 126.9(3) 160.1(6) 115.8(3)−122.0(3) 100.2(2)−114.1(2) Py−Si−Py (deg) 107.6(4) 105.9(7)−109.7(7) 108.3(4), 107.4(5) 104.8(3)−107.9(3) Ag···X (Å) 2.43(1), 2.51(1) 2.51(4) 2.882(3) >3.00 coord number 5 2, 3 3 4 motif double helix interwoven nanotube ladder tube network

a  Reference 19.

The molecular structure of [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2·2CH3OH is depicted in Figure , and selected data are listed in Table . Its skeleton is a ladder structure consisting of a 2:3 ratio of Ag(I) and L. Three pyridyl moieties connect a Ag(I) ion (Ag−N = 2.248(7), 2.244(1), and 2.311(8) Å) to form a ladder structure. Thus, the geometry around the Ag(I) ion approximates a trigonal arrangement (N−Ag−N = 115.8(3)−122.0(3)°). The most fascinating feature is that the top view of the molecular ladder is an elegant tubular structure. The molecular tube has a 14 Å × 12 Å cross section. The triflate anion does not significantly interact with the Ag(I) ion and, thus, acts as a simple counteranion (Ag···O = 2.882(3) Å).
elements.clean_text: The molecular structure of [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2⋅2CH3OH is depicted in Figure , and selected data are listed in Table . Its skeleton is a ladder structure consisting of a 2:3 ratio of Ag(I) and L. Three pyridyl moieties connect a Ag(I) ion (Ag-N = 2.248(7), 2.244(1), and 2.311(8) Å) to form a ladder structure. Thus, the geometry around the Ag(I) ion approximates a trigonal arrangement (N-Ag-N = 115.8(3)-122.0(3)°). The most fascinating feature is that the top view of the molecular ladder is an elegant tubular structure.  The molecular tube has a 14 Å × 12 Å cross section. The triflate anion does not significantly interact with the Ag(I) ion and, thus, acts as a simple counteranion (Ag⋅⋅⋅O = 2.882(3) Å).

elements.content: For the PF6 - analogue, the skeletal structure is simple networks consisting of a 1:2 mole ratio of Ag and L. The crystal structure is shown in Figure , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . Each L connects two Ag(I) ions (Ag−N = 2.266(5)−2.419(5) Å) to form a [Ag(L)2]4 rectangle (11 Å × 11 Å) motif. For the network structure, the geometry around the Ag(I) is a distorted tetrahedral arrangement (N−Ag−N = 96.7(2)−124.8(2)°). The PF6 - anion exist as a simple counteranion. The crystal is composed of abab... layers.

The crystal structure is shown in Figure , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . Each L connects two Ag(I) ions (Ag-N = 2.266(5)-2.419(5) Å) to form a [Ag(L)2]4 rectangle (11 Å × 11 Å) motif. For the network structure, the geometry around the Ag(I) is a distorted tetrahedral arrangement (N-Ag-N = 96.7(2)-124.8(2)°). The PF6 - anion exist as a simple counteranion. The crystal is composed of abab... layers.

elements.content: Schematic diagram (top), geometry around silver(I) (top), and infinite structure (bottom) of [Ag(L)2](PF6). Hydrogen and hexafluorophophate anions were omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic diagram (top), geometry around silver(I) (top), and infinite structure (bottom) of [Ag(L)2](PF6). Hydrogen and hexafluorophophate anions were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Construction Principle. A combination of a variety of geometries of Ag(I) ions and the appropriate length, conformation, angle, and steric effects of the L ligand seems to afford characteristic structures with various ratios of L to Ag(I). Each skeleton was exclusively constructed irrespective of the mole ratio of the reactants, the solvent types, and the concentrations. The Ag(I):L ratios of the products (1:1, 3:4, 2:3, and 1:2) are dependent on the anions. First of all, the PF6 - anion that has been considered as a common “noncoordinating” anion39 has little tendency to serve as a ligand in the present structure. Such noncoordinating anions afford the spacer-abundant 1:2 adducts of [Ag(L)2](PF6). On the other hand, a relatively coordinating anion, NO2 -, affords the 1:1 adduct of [Ag(NO2)(L)]. The moderately coordinating NO3 - anion produces [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 (3:4). Triflate anion affords the 2:3 adduct of [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2. The ratios are exactly coincident with the order of the coordinating ability of the anions that was established in our previous paper.
elements.clean_text: Construction Principle. A combination of a variety of geometries of Ag(I) ions and the appropriate length, conformation, angle, and steric effects of the L ligand seems to afford characteristic structures with various ratios of L to Ag(I). Each skeleton was exclusively constructed irrespective of the mole ratio of the reactants, the solvent types, and the concentrations. The Ag(I):L ratios of the products (1:1, 3:4, 2:3, and 1:2) are dependent on the anions. First of all, the PF6 - anion that has been considered as a common "noncoordinating" anion39 has little tendency to serve as a ligand  in the present structure. Such noncoordinating anions afford the spacer-abundant 1:2 adducts of [Ag(L)2](PF6). On the other hand, a relatively coordinating anion, NO2 -, affords the 1:1 adduct of [Ag(NO2)(L)]. The moderately coordinating NO3 - anion produces [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 (3:4). Triflate anion affords the 2:3 adduct of [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2. The ratios are exactly coincident with the order of the coordinating ability of the anions that was established in our previous paper.

elements.content: For [Ag(NO2)(L)], the NO2 - anion acts as a chelate ligand rather than a simple counteranion. The bond length of Ag−O is 2.43(1) and 2.51(1) Å, and thus, the bond angle of N−Ag−N (126.9(3)°) is concomitantly bent. Furthermore, the coordinating NO2 - moiety partly seems to induce a double-helical motif. The double helices are connected to each other via the Ag···Ag interaction (3.002(2) Å) to form a characteristic molecular sheet. For [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 and [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2, the shortest Ag···NO3 - (2.51 Å)19 and Ag(I)···CF3SO3 - (2.88 Å) distances are less than the sum of the van der Waals radii (3.20 Å) of Ag and O. The L/M ratios as well as the local geometries of the products appear to be delicately associated with the coordinating nature of the anions. The L/M ratios increase with decreasing order of coordinating ability, NO2 - < NO3 - < CF3SO3 - < PF6 -, as shown in Figure . For the products with noncoordinating anions, no π−π interaction exists, in contrast to 2,4‘-Py2S analogues, presumably owing to the presence of the bulky dimethyl groups. The bond angles of Py−Si−Py (104.8(1)−108.2(1)°) are almost constant, indicating that the present ligand is relatively rigid.
elements.clean_text: For [Ag(NO2)(L)], the NO2 - anion acts as a chelate ligand rather than a simple counteranion. The bond length of Ag-O is 2.43(1) and 2.51(1) Å, and thus, the bond angle of N-Ag-N (126.9(3)°) is concomitantly bent. Furthermore, the coordinating NO2 - moiety partly seems to induce a double-helical motif. The double helices are connected to each other via the Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction (3.002(2) Å) to form a characteristic molecular sheet. For [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 and [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2, the shortest Ag⋅⋅⋅NO3 - (2.51 Å)19 and Ag(I)⋅⋅⋅CF3SO3 - (2.88 Å) distances are less than the sum of the van der Waals radii (3.20 Å) of Ag and O. The L/M ratios as well as the local geometries of the products appear to be delicately associated with the coordinating nature of the anions. The L/M ratios increase with decreasing order of coordinating ability, NO2 - < NO3 - < CF3SO3 - < PF6 -, as shown in Figure . For the products with noncoordinating anions, no π-π interaction exists, in contrast to 2,4‘-Py2S analogues, presumably owing to the presence of the bulky dimethyl groups. The bond angles of Py-Si-Py (104.8(1)-108.2(1)°) are almost constant, indicating that the present ligand is relatively rigid.

elements.content: Correlation between the L:Ag(I) ratio and the coordination ability of the anions.
elements.clean_text: 4  Correlation between the L:Ag(I) ratio and the coordination ability of the anions.

elements.content: Thermal Properties. All crystals are insoluble in water and common organic solvents. The products are air-stable, but slowly turn to gray powder under light. The crystalline solids are easily dissociated in dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylformamide, or acetonitrile. The thermal stabilities are dependent upon the structural properties. For [Ag(NO2)(L)], the thermal analyses (TGA and DSC) (Supporting Information) show a drastic decomposition around 164 °C. The collapse at low temperature relative to that of [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 (231 °C)19 may be ascribed to the angle constraint of the chelating NO2 - moiety and the inter-double-helical argentophilic interaction. [Ag(L)2](PF6) is stable up to 210 °C. The TGA and DSC overlay of [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2 indicates that the tubular structure is stable up to 252 °C, indicating that the tube structure is more or less rigid.
elements.clean_text: Thermal Properties. All crystals are insoluble in water and common organic solvents. The products are air-stable, but slowly turn to gray powder under light. The crystalline solids are easily dissociated in dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylformamide, or acetonitrile. The thermal stabilities are dependent upon the structural properties. For [Ag(NO2)(L)], the thermal analyses (TGA and DSC) (Supporting Information) show a drastic decomposition around 164 °C. The collapse at low temperature relative to that of [Ag3(L)4](NO3)3 (231 °C)19 may be ascribed to the angle constraint of the chelating NO2 - moiety and the inter-double-helical argentophilic interaction. [Ag(L)2](PF6) is stable up to 210 °C. The TGA and DSC overlay of [Ag2(L)3](CF3SO3)2 indicates that the tubular structure is stable up to 252 °C, indicating that the tube structure is more or less rigid.

elements.content: In conclusion, our results demonstrate that the silicon-based bipyridine spacer is a fascinating molecular building unit that exhibits little strain in the construction of various skeletons such as a double-helical sheet with a ligand-unsupported Ag···Ag interaction in five-coordinate Ag(I) compounds, a sheet consisting of nanotubes, ladder type tubes, and 2D sheets. In particular, the L/M ratios of the products are strongly dependent upon the coordinating order of the anions. A new coordinating series of polyatomic anions may be used to quantitatively predict and synthesize the desired structures.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, our results demonstrate that the silicon-based bipyridine spacer is a fascinating molecular building unit that exhibits little strain in the construction of various skeletons such as a double-helical sheet with a ligand-unsupported Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interaction in five-coordinate Ag(I) compounds, a sheet consisting of nanotubes, ladder type tubes, and 2D sheets. In particular, the L/M ratios of the products are strongly dependent upon the coordinating order of the anions. A new coordinating series of polyatomic anions may be used to quantitatively predict and synthesize the desired structures.

cln_elements.content:
[Ag(NO 2 )(L)]. A methanol solution (6 mL) of L (43 mg, 0.20 mmol) was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution (6 mL) of AgNO2 (30 mg, 0.20 mmol). Colorless crystals of [Ag(NO2)(L)] formed at the interface, and were obtained in 6 days in 70% yield. Mp:  164 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C12H14N3O2SiAg:  C, 39.14; H, 3.83; N, 11.41. Found:  C, 40.04; H, 3,77; N, 11.14. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν(NO2), 1254 (s).

[Ag 2 (L) 3 ](CF 3 SO 3 ) 2 . A methanol solution of L was slowly diffused into an aqueous solution of AgCF3SO3 in a mole ratio of 1:1. Yield: 70% based on Ag(I) salt. Mp:  252 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C38H42N6O6F6S2Si3Ag2:  C, 39.45; H, 3.66; N, 7.26. Found:  C, 40.01; H, 3,76; N, 7.24. The crystals were obtained as a methanol solvate, but the elemental analysis was accomplished after desolvation under vacuum. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν(CF3SO3), 814 (s).

[Ag(L) 2 ](PF 6 ). This reaction was carried out by a similar method using acetone instead of methanol as a solvent. Yield:  70%. Mp:  210 °C dec. Anal. Calcd for C24H28N4PF6Si2Ag:  C, 42.40; H, 4.14; N, 8.22. Found:  C, 42.30; H, 4.18; N, 8.48. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν(PF6), 838 (s). The crystals were obtained as an acetone solvate, but the elemental analysis was accomplished after desolvation under vacuum.

metadata.title:
Relationship between the Ratio of Ligand to Metal and the Coordinating
Ability of Anions. Synthesis and Structural Properties of AgX-Bearing
Bis(4-pyridyl)dimethylsilane (X- = NO2
-, NO3
-, CF3SO3
-, and PF6
-)
